awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Nucleon Structure, Fundamental Symmetries, and Lattice QCD
awd_abstract_narration:
Protons and neutrons are the basic building blocks of all visible matter. They were created in the Big Bang together with antiprotons and antineutrons. It is unknown why more particles than antiparticles have been created in the early Universe, and it is the particles that have survived to become all of the presently existing nuclear matter. Such an imbalance may occur only if physical laws are not exactly symmetric when time is reversed. If this is the case, nuclear experiments must observe precession (rotation) of neutrons in an electric field. In the next decade the precision of such experiments will be improved 100-fold. This project is aimed at providing the theoretical foundations to examine whether experiments agree with known interactions of elementary particles or not, and measure how much the space reflection and time reversal symmetries of physical laws are broken. These questions are at the heart of modern nuclear physics and they have to be answered to understand the origin of all known matter.

Electric dipole moments (EDMs) of nucleons (protons and neutrons), nuclei, and atoms can be induced by time reversal (T) symmetry-violating interactions of elementary particles that comprise them. While the standard model contains T violation, the violation is not sufficiently large to produce the observed baryon asymmetry of the Universe. This alone points to new, yet unknown types of particle interactions, such as color-electric dipole moments of quarks, three-gluon, and four-quark effective interactions. EDMs of nucleons and nuclei may also be produced by nontrivial topology of gauge fields (the so-called theta-term) that has not been observed so far. While the theory governing quarks and gluons is known, it is intractable analytically, and requires numerical calculations (lattice QCD) to compute nucleon structure and EDMs, which is the aim of this project. Current and future experiments measuring EDMs are thus at the frontier of fundamental physics. Their interpretation, however, depends critically on precise theoretical calculations of nucleon structure that will be performed in this project.

por.por_cntn:
Hard-to-detect phenomena such as proton decays, neutron-antineutron oscillations, and electric dipole moments of protons and neutrons hold keys to the puzzle of origin of all nuclear matter in the Universe. The primary goal of this project was to study what these effects can tell us about fundamental symmetries and their violations, baryon number and charge-parity (CP). These violations almost certainly have to be caused by some new particles and interactions. Although very tiny, their size and nature are directly related to the amount of baryonic matter that have survived after the Big Bang.

One of the outcomes of the project is a firm determination that absence of proton decays in experiments cannot be caused just by dynamics of quarks and gluons, the proton constituents. It indeed teaches us that simple models of Grand Unification cannot explain nuclear matter existence. To make this conclusion, extensive calculations on a lattice were required. Another goal of this project was to study how neutron and proton electric dipole moment (nEDM) can be induced by CP-violating interactions. We have developed a novel methodology that relies on uniform background electric field to overcome statistical and systematical uncertainties. This opens the door to studying the so-called QCD theta-term, which is specific to gluon fields binding quarks together, which is very small and difficult to detect. It will also simplify studying other CP-violating interactions, for example, in scattering of quarks due to yet unknown forces.

Another outcome is input to collider experiments studying nuclear structure and looking for new particles in high-energy colliders. In order to detect new particles, structure of nucleons and mesons must be known with high resolution (at high energy). In the course of the project, charge and magnetization distributions in protons, neutrons, and light mesons were computed up to momenta 10 GeV^2. These data will be compared to results of the upcoming Electron-Ion Collider (EIC), used in the experimental analysis of three-dimensional structure of the proton, neutron, and nuclei, and will eventually be incorporated into searches of new particles at the LHC and future similar experiments.

So-called inelastic high-energy collisions produce large number of particles indicating high disorder and hot temperature. Explaining this is difficult because in such collisions, there is not enough time and space to reach thermal equilibrium. This disorder, or entropy, is likely produced from quantum entanglement inside the nucleons. It has long been assumed that quarks are bound by a so-called color flux tube. As an novel direction of the project, we have defined a way to compute this entropy from quantum gluon (color) fields themselves. Our results match previous expectations, but have been obtained on a fundamental level. For the first time, we have demonstrated that quantum entanglement leads to unambiguous results in quantum gauge theories, which will also have great impact on studying quantum information and entanglement in other areas of physics. We plan to apply this method next to study the flux tubes and their junctions between three valence quarks in the proton and the neutron, and what happens to them as the temperature is increased until they "melt" into quarks and gluons. 

During the project, two postdoctoral fellows and three graduate students have been trained in computing methods, nuclear physics, and related areas. Two of them work in national labs continuing research in fundamental physics and national security applications, respectively. Another former postdoctoral fellow works in applications of computing methods to medical imaging. The most recent graduate student leading the work on color flux tube quantum entanglement is expected to defend his thesis and graduate in Summer 2025. His training and research are at the interface of nuclear physics and quantum information, both of which are important areas of national interest and security.
